Nature 403:853-858.", "link":"http://www.cepf.net/resources/hotspots/Pages/default.aspx"}

attributes.name: Interannual variability
attributes.info: {"description":"Interannual variability of total annual precipitation. Calculated as the coefficient of variation (standard deviation divided by the mean, multiplied by 100 to convert to a percentage). Calculated from 1985-2015 data from the Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station (CHIRPS) version 2.0 dataset.", "source":"Funk, C.C., Peterson, P.J., Landsfeld, M.F., Pedreros, D.H., Verdin, J.P., Rowland, J.D., Romero, B.E., Husak, G.J., Michaelsen, J.C., and Verdin, A.P., 2014, A quasi-global precipitation time series for drought monitoring: U.S. Geological Survey Data Series 832, 4 p. ", "link":"http://chg.geog.ucsb.edu/data/chirps/" }

attributes.name: Land cover
attributes.info: {"description":"Data is a global land-cover classification map produced by the European Space Agency in 2009. ", "source":"ESA and the Université Catholique de Louvain, 2010.", "link":"http://due.esrin.esa.int/page_globcover.php" }
attributes.css:
#horncover {raster-opacity:1; 
  	raster-colorizer-default-mode: discrete; 
  	raster-colorizer-default-color: transparent; 
  	raster-colorizer-epsilon: 0.01; 
  	raster-colorizer-stops: 
    	stop(11, rgba(170,240,240,1))
        stop(14, rgba(255,255,100,1))
        stop(20, rgba(220,240,100,1))
        stop(30, rgba(205,205,102,1))
        stop(40, rgba(0,100,0,1))
        stop(50, rgba(0,160,0,1))
        stop(60, rgba(170,200,0,1))
        stop(70, rgba(0,60,0,1))
        stop(90, rgba(40,100,0,1))
        stop(100, rgba(120,130,0,1))
        stop(110, rgba(140,160,0,1))
        stop(120, rgba(190,150,0,1))
        stop(130, rgba(150,100,0,1))
        stop(140, rgba(255,180,50,1))
        stop(150, rgba(255,235,175,1))
        stop(160, rgba(0,120,90,1))
        stop(170, rgba(0,150,120,1))
        stop(180, rgba(0,220,130,1))
        stop(190, rgba(195,20,0,1))
        stop(200, rgba(255,245,215,1))
        stop(210, transparent)
        stop(220, rgba(255,255,255,1))
        stop(230, rgba(0,0,0,1))
}
attributes.query:
SELECT the_raster_webmercator FROM horncover
union 
SELECT the_raster_webmercator FROM shaelcover
union 
SELECT the_raster_webmercator FROM asiasover

attributes.name: Focal geographies
attributes.css: #grp_horn_1m_dissolved_20151021{ polygon-fill: #0089CC; polygon-opacity: 0.1; line-color: #0089CC; line-width: 1; line-opacity: 0.7; line-join:round; } #grp_horn_1m_dissolved_20151021::labels[region!='Horn of Africa'][zoom<5] { text-name: [region]; text-face-name: 'DejaVu Sans Book'; text-size: 14; text-label-position-tolerance: 10; text-fill: #0089CC; text-halo-fill: #dddddd; text-halo-radius: 0.5; text-dy: 0; text-dx:0; text-allow-overlap: true; text-placement: point; text-placement-type: simple; text-wrap-width: 50; text-wrap-before: false; } #grp_horn_1m_dissolved_20151021::labels[region='Horn of Africa'][zoom<5] { text-name: [region]; text-face-name: 'DejaVu Sans Book'; text-size: 14; text-label-position-tolerance: 10; text-fill: #0089CC; text-halo-fill: #dddddd; text-halo-radius: 0.5; text-dy: 0; text-dx: 0; text-allow-overlap: true; text-placement: point; text-placement-type: simple; text-wrap-width: 50; text-wrap-before: false; }
attributes.query: SELECT the_geom_webmercator, the_geom, 'Sahel' as region FROM grp_sahel_1m_dissolved_20151021 union SELECT the_geom_webmercator, the_geom, 'Horn of Africa' as region FROM grp_horn_1m_dissolved_20151021 union SELECT ST_collect(the_geom_webmercator) as the_geom_webmercator, ST_collect(the_geom) as the_geom, 'South and Southeast Asia' as region FROM grp_asia_1m_dissolved_20151021

attributes.name: Trend in rainy season precipitation (wetter rainy season)
attributes.info: {"description":"Trend in precipitation during the rainy season over the 1985-2015 period. For countries with two rainy seasons, this is the trend of the wetter of the two seasons.  polygon-fill: #FFFFFF; polygon-opacity: 0.5; line-color: #5CA2D1; line-width: 0.5; line-opacity: 1; } #nutrition_tza_national_csv::labels { text-name: [round]; text-face-name: 'DejaVu Sans Book'; text-size: 10; text-label-position-tolerance: 10; text-fill: #000; text-halo-fill: #FFF; text-halo-radius: 0; text-dy: -10; text-allow-overlap: false; text-placement: point; text-placement-type: simple; }
attributes.query: SELECT s.the_geom_webmercator, round(wasting::numeric,4), year FROM nutrition_tza_national_csv r inner join country_mask s on r.country=s.iso_a3

attributes.query: SELECT t1.country, t2.the_geom_webmercator,  t1.landscape, round(wasting::numeric,4) FROM nutrition_vs_landscape_csv t1 left join coordinates_landscapes_wgs_84 t2 ON t1.country = t2.country and t2.landscape__ = t1.landscape

attributes.name: Top three exports: tea production
attributes.query:
SELECT p2.the_geom_webmercator, p2.the_geom, p1.iso3, teas::float ,unit FROM spam2005v2r0_grp_production p1 inner join spam_polygons_grp p2 on p1.alloc_id=p2.alloc_id
inner join grpcountries_250k_polygon p3 on p1.iso3= p3.iso3 where teas::float != 0

Stevens, Forrest R., et al. “Disaggregating Census Data for Population Mapping Using Random Forests with Remotely-Sensed and Ancillary Data.” PLoS ONE 10, no. 2 (February 17, 2015): e0107042.

Alegana, V. A., et al. “Fine Resolution Mapping of Population Age-Structures for Health and Development Applications.” Journal of The Royal Society Interface 12, no. 105 (April 6, 2015).

Deville, Pierre, et al. “Dynamic Population Mapping Using Mobile Phone Data.” Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 111, no. 45 (November 11, 2014): 15888–93.

Linard, Catherine, et al. “Population Distribution, Settlement Patterns and Accessibility across Africa in 2010.” PLoS ONE 7, no. 2 (February 21, 2012): e31743.

Gaughan, Andrea E. et al. “High Resolution Population Distribution Maps for Southeast Asia in 2010 and 2015.” PLoS ONE 8, no. 2 (February 13, 2013): e55882.

Tatem, Andrew J., et al. “High Resolution Population Maps for Low Income Nations: Combining Land Cover and Census in East Africa.” PLoS ONE 2, no. 12 (December 12, 2007): e1298.

", "link":"www.worldpop.org.uk" }

SELECT element, t1.iso3, item, y2013, unit, the_geom, the_geom_webmercator FROM t1 INNER JOIN grpcountries_250k_polygon t2 ON t1.iso3 = t2.iso3 where rn = 1

attributes.name: Projected change (2040-2060, RCP8.5)
attributes.info:
{"description":"Change in annual mean daily mean surface temperature for 2040-2060, in degrees Celsius, compared to the 1980-2000 period. This layer uses downscaled data from the 5th Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5) made available in the the NASA Earth Exchange Global Daily Downscaled Projections (NEX-GDDP) dataset. The data for this layer is from the RCP8.5 scenario, a scenario that results in CO2 concentrations of more than 1370 ppm by 2100.", "source":"

Moss, Richard H., Jae A. Edmonds, Kathy A. Hibbard, Martin R. Manning, Steven K. Rose, Detlef P. van Vuuren, Timothy R. Carter, et al. 'The next Generation of Scenarios for Climate Change Research and Assessment.' Nature 463, no. 7282 (February 11, 2010): 747–56.

attributes.analysis_query:
SELECT (ST_Histogram(ST_Union(ST_SetBandNoDataValue(the_raster_webmercator, -9999)),1,true)).*  
FROM total_annual_rainfall
where st_intersects(the_raster_webmercator, st_transform(ST_SetSRID (ST_GeomFromGeoJSON('{{geometry}}'),4326),3857))

This layer uses downscaled data from the 5th Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5) made available in the the NASA Earth Exchange Global Daily Downscaled Projections (NEX-GDDP) dataset. The data for this layer is from the RCP4.5 scenario, a scenario that results in CO2 concentrations stabilizing at about 650 ppm by 2100.", "source":"

Moss, Richard H., Jae A. Edmonds, Kathy A. Hibbard, Martin R. Manning, Steven K. Rose, Detlef P. van Vuuren, Timothy R. Carter, et al. “The next Generation of Scenarios for Climate Change Research and Assessment.” Nature 463, no. 7282 (February 11, 2010): 747–56.

Taylor, Karl E., Ronald J. Stouffer, and Gerald A. Meehl. 'An Overview of CMIP5 and the Experiment Design' Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society 93, no. 4 (2012): 485–98.

", "link":"http://dx.doi.org/10.7292/W0MW2F2G" }

attributes.name: Projected change (2080-2100, RCP8.5)
attributes.info:
{"description":"Percent change in mean total annual precipitation for 2800-2100, compared to the 1980-2000 period. This layer uses downscaled data from the 5th Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5) made available in the the NASA Earth Exchange Global Daily Downscaled Projections (NEX-GDDP) dataset. The data for this layer is from the RCP8.5 scenario, a scenario that results in CO2 concentrations of more than 1370 ppm by 2100.", "source":"

attributes.query: SELECT the_geom, the_geom_webmercator,iso3,lz_type, lz_value FROM grp_africa_livelihoodzones union SELECT the_geom, the_geom_webmercator,iso3,lz_type, lz_value FROM grp_asia_livelihoodzones
attributes.dataset_shortname: FEWSNET. Livelihoods: Insights into how people survive and prosper [Internet]. [updated 21 January, 2015]. Available: https://www.fews.net/sectors/livelihoods [cited 21 October 2015]

attributes.name: Top exports by total production
attributes.info: {"description":"Data is from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations - Statistics Division; Trade indices for crops and livestock indicate the values for export in 1000$.", "source":"", "link":"http://faostat3.fao.org/download/Q/QC/E" }
attributes.query:
with t1 as (SELECT iso3, item, unit, value, row_number() over ( partition by iso3 order by value desc) as rn FROM trade_crops_livestock_e_all_data_grp where value != 0 and element='Export Quantity' and year = 2011)
select t1.iso3, item, unit, value, the_geom_webmercator, the_geom from t1 INNER JOIN grpcountries_250k_polygon t2 ON t1.iso3 = t2.iso3 where rn = 1
attributes.legend: {"type": "custom", "data": [ { "name": "Animal Vegetable Oil + (Total)", "value": "#1b9e77" }, { "name": "Cashew nuts, with shell", "value": "#d95f02" }, { "name": "Cassava Equivalent + (Total)", "value": "#7570b3" }, { "name": "Cereals + (Total)", "value": "#e7298a" }, { "name": "Cocoa, beans", "value": "#FB9A99" }, { "name": "Meal, meat", "value": "#E31A1C" }, { "name": "Oilseeds + (Total)", "value": "#FDBF6F" }, { "name": "Onions, dry", "value": "#FF7F00" }, { "name": "Sugar,Total (Raw Equiv.) + (Total)", "value": "#CAB2D6" },{ "name": "Textile Fibres + (Total)", "value": "#6A3D9A" } ] }

attributes.name: Top exports by value
attributes.info: {"description":"Data is from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations - Statistics Division; Trade indices for crops and livestock indicate the values for export in 1000$.", "source":"", "link":"http://faostat3.fao.org/download/Q/QC/E" }
attributes.query:
with t1 as (SELECT iso3, item, unit, value, row_number() over ( partition by iso3 order by value desc) as rn FROM trade_crops_livestock_e_all_data_grp where value != 0 and element='Export Value' and year = 2011 and item not like'%Total%')

select t1.iso3, item, unit, value, the_geom_webmercator, the_geom from t1 INNER JOIN grpcountries_250k_polygon t2 ON t1.iso3 = t2.iso3 where rn = 1
attributes.legend: {"type": "custom", "data": [ { "name": "Cocoa, beans", "value": "#1b9e77" }, { "name": "Coffee, green", "value": "#d95f02" }, { "name": "Cotton lint", "value": "#7570b3" }, { "name": "Nutmeg, mace and cardamoms", "value": "#e7298a" }, { "name": "Oil, palm", "value": "#FB9A99" }, { "name": "Rice  total  (Rice milled equivalent)", "value": "#E31A1C" }, { "name": "Rubber natural dry", "value": "#FDBF6F" }, { "name": "Sesame seed", "value": "#FF7F00" }, { "name": "Sugar refined", "value": "#CAB2D6" },{ "name": "Tea", "value": "#6A3D9A" } ] }

attributes.query:
SELECT t1.the_geom_webmercator, t2.regionid, t2.surveyyear, CN_NUTS_C_WH2 as value FROM dhs_regions t1
left join dhs_indicators t2 ON t1.regionid = t2.regionid
where surveyyear >= 2006

attributes.name: Urban areas (circa 2030)
attributes.info:
{"description":"The Global Grid of Probabilities of Urban Expansion to 2030 presents spatially explicit probabilistic forecasts of global urban land cover change from 2000 to 2030 at a 2.5 arc-minute resolution. For each grid cell that is non-urban in 2000, a Monte-Carlo model assigned a probability of becoming urban by the year 2030. The authors first extracted urban extent circa 2000 from the NASA MODIS Land Cover Type Product Version 5, which provides a conservative estimate of global urban land cover. The authors then used population densities from the Global Rural-Urban Mapping Project, Version 1 (GRUMPv1) to create the population density driver map. They estimated the amount of new urban land in each United Nations region by 2030 in a Monte-Carlo fashion based on present empirical distribution of regional urban population densities and probability density functions of projected regional population and GDP values for 2030. To facilitate integration with other data products, CIESIN reprojected the data from Goode's Homolosine to Geographic WGS84 projection.", "source":"

Seto, K., B. Güneralp, and L.R. Hutyra. 2015. Global Grid of Probabilities of Urban Expansion to 2030. Palisades, NY: NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC). http://dx.doi.org/10.7927/H4Z899CG. Accessed 30 Nov 2016.

Seto, K., B. Güneralp, and L.R. Hutyra. 2012. Global Forecasts of Urban Expansion to 2030 and Direct Impacts on Biodiversity and Carbon Pools. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America 109 (40): 16083-16088. http://dx.doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1211658109.

", "link":"http://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/data/set/lulc-global-grid-prob-urban-expansion-2030" }
attributes.dataset_shortname:
Seto, K., B. Güneralp, and L.R. Hutyra. 2015. Global Grid of Probabilities of Urban Expansion to 2030. Palisades, NY: NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC). http://dx.doi.org/10.7927/H4Z899CG. Accessed 30 Nov 2016.

Seto, K., B. Güneralp, and L.R. Hutyra. 2012. Global Forecasts of Urban Expansion to 2030 and Direct Impacts on Biodiversity and Carbon Pools. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America 109 (40): 16083-16088. http://dx.doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1211658109.

attributes.name: Urban areas (circa 2000)
attributes.info:
{"description":"Map of urban land area produced using satellite imagery from 2000-2001, at 500 meter resolution. Urban areas are areas where the built environment covers at least 50% of the pixel area. The \"built environment\" is defined as all non-vegetative, human-constructed elements of the landscape.", "source":"

attributes.name: Marine plastic
attributes.info: {"description":"Marine plastic pollution is modeled using data on the global distribution of floating marine plastics at 0.2 degree resolution (Erikson et al. 2014). Specifically, weight of floating plastics (g/km2) across four different size classes were aggregated to represent total weight of plastic debris per km2. These data were log transformed and rescaled from 0 to 1 using the 99.99th quantile as the reference point.","source":"Ocean Health Index. 2017. ohi-global version: Global scenarios data for Ocean Health Index, June 6, 2019. attributes.name: Coral reefs
attributes.info:
{"description":"This dataset shows the global distribution of coral reefs in tropical and subtropical regions. It is the most comprehensive global dataset of warm-water coral reefs to date, acting as a foundation baseline map for future, more detailed, work. This dataset was compiled from a number of sources by UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre (UNEP-WCMC) and the WorldFish Centre, in collaboration with WRI (World Resources Institute) and TNC (The Nature Conservancy). Data sources include the Millennium Coral Reef Mapping Project (IMaRS-USF and IRD 2005, IMaRS-USF 2005) and the World Atlas of Coral Reefs (Spalding et al. 2001).", "source":"UNEP-WCMC, WorldFish Centre, WRI, TNC (2010). Global distribution of coral reefs, compiled from multiple sources including the Millennium Coral Reef Mapping Project. Version 2.0, updated by UNEP-WCMC. Includes contributions from IMaRSUSF and IRD (2005), IMaRS-USF (2005) and Spalding et al. (2001). Cambridge (UK): UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre. URL: http://data.unepwcmc.org/datasets/1

attributes.name: Mangroves
attributes.info: {"description":"The Global Mangrove Watch (GMW) was initiated as part of the K&C Initiative in 2011. It is led by Aberystwyth University (U.K.) and solo Earth Observation (Sweden), in collaboration with Wetlands International, the International Water Management Institute (Laos) and the UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre (U.K.). The GMW aims to provide geospatial information about mangrove extent and changes to the Ramsar Convention, national wetland practitioners, decision makers and NGOs. It is part of the Ramsar Science and Technical Review Panel (STRP) work plan for 2016-2018 and a Pilot Project to the Ramsar Global Wetlands Observation System (GWOS), which is implemented under the GEO-Wetlands Initiative. The primary objective of the GMW has been to provide countries lacking a national mangrove monitoring system with first cut mangrove extent and change maps, to help safeguard against further mangrove forest loss and degradation.", "source":"Bunting P., Rosenqvist A., Lucas R., Rebelo L-M., Hilarides L., Thomas N., Hardy A., Itoh T., Shimada M. and Finlayson C.M. (2018). The Global Mangrove Watch – a New 2010 Global Baseline of Mangrove Extent. Remote Sensing, 2018 [under review].","link":"http://www.eorc.jaxa.jp/ALOS/en/kyoto/mangrovewatch.htm"}

attributes.name: Sea Surface Temperature (2011)
attributes.info: {"description":"The sea level rise pressure layer is derived from satellite altimetry data (http://www.aviso.altimetry.fr/en/data/products/sea-surface-height-products/global/msla-mean-climatology.html). Monthly mean sea level anomalies since 1993 track changes in sea level (mm) compared to a reference period from 1993-2012. Raw monthly data are provided on a 0.25x0.25 degree grid. These data were clipped to within 3 nautical miles of the coast, and monthly data layers were aggregated and averaged across pixels to compute mean sea level anomalies. The 99.99th quantile of raster values from all years was used as the reference point to rescale the layer from 0 to 1. All negative values were set to zero (i.e., no negative pressure), such that only positive sea level rise values mattered. The mean value of the raster cells within each OHI region was calculated.","source":"Ocean Health Index. 2017. ohi-global version: Global scenarios data for Ocean Health Index, June 6, 2019. National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis, University of California, Santa Barbara. Available at: https://rawgit.com/OHI-Science/ftp_data/master/data_list.html","link":"https://rawgit.com/OHI-Science/ftp_data/master/data_list.html"}

attributes.name: Ocean Acidification (2013)
attributes.info: {"description":"Models the difference in global distribution of the aragonite saturation state of the ocean in the pre-industrial era and modern times. Global estimates through time (Feely et al. 2009) are modeled at 1-degree resolution. Changes in the saturation state can be attributed to changes in the concentration of CO2 and thus we use the difference between the pre-industrial and modern times as a proxy for ocean acidification due to human influences. Values are rescaled from 0 to 1 using the threshold at which seawater becomes undersaturated.","source":"Ocean Health Index. 2017. ohi-global version: Global scenarios data for Ocean Health Index, June 6, 2019. National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis, University of California, Santa Barbara. attributes.name: Sea Level Rise (2012)
attributes.info: {"description":"The sea level rise pressure layer is derived from satellite altimetry data (http://www.aviso.altimetry.fr/en/data/products/sea-surface-height-products/global/msla-mean-climatology.html). Monthly mean sea level anomalies since 1993 track changes in sea level (mm) compared to a reference period from 1993-2012. Raw monthly data are provided on a 0.25x0.25 degree grid. These data were clipped to within 3 nautical miles of the coast, and monthly data layers were aggregated and averaged across pixels to compute mean sea level anomalies. The 99.99th quantile of raster values from all years was used as the reference point to rescale the layer from 0 to 1. All negative values were set to zero (i.e., no negative pressure), such that only positive sea level rise values mattered. The mean value of the raster cells within each OHI region was calculated.","source":"Ocean Health Index. 2017. ohi-global version: Global scenarios data for Ocean Health Index, June 6, 2019. National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis, University of California, Santa Barbara. Available at: https://rawgit.com/OHI-Science/ftp_data/master/data_list.html","link":"https://rawgit.com/OHI-Science/ftp_data/master/data_list.html"}

attributes.name: Velocity of Temperature Change RCP8.5 2060-80 Neotropics
attributes.info: {"description":"Velocity (km/yr) of species movement.","source":"CI","link":"http://www.conservation.org"}

attributes.name: Priority of the Neotropics
attributes.info: {"description":"Priorities were produced using Zonation software to identify areas most important for additional conservation for both current climates and projected future climates.  Priorities involved modeled species ranges (current and projected) for over 20,000 plant and animal species.  Priorities shown here are re-ordered within each country -- i.e. highest priority areas are if each country were to plan individually.  This produces different priorities than planning on a regional or continental scale.  Setting the visualizer tool to e.g. 30% shows the highest priority areas for every country to achieve 30% coverage of conserved area. Funding provided by the Global Environment Facility.","source":"CI-SPARC","link":"https://www.conservation.org/gef/projects/Pages/SPARC.aspx"}

attributes.info: {"description":"Priorities were produced using Zonation software to identify areas most important for additional conservation for both current climates and projected future climates.  Priorities involved modeled species ranges (current and projected) for over 20,000 plant and animal species.  Priorities shown here are re-ordered within each country -- i.e. highest priority areas are if each country were to plan individually.  This produces different priorities than planning on a regional or continental scale.  Setting the visualizer tool to e.g. 30% shows the highest priority areas for every country to achieve 30% coverage of conserved area. attributes.name: Productivity trajectory
attributes.info:
{"description":"This layer demonstrate the trend of NDVI (using MODIS (MOD13Q1, annual datasets) masked for the significant values of the trajectory of productivity over time (2001-2015). Land productivity is the total above-ground net primary productivity defined as the energy fixed by plants minus their respiration which translates into the rate of biomass accumulation that delivers a suite of ecosystem services. This sub-indicator points to changes in the health and productive capacity of the land and reflects the net effects of changes in ecosystem functioning on plant and biomass growth, where declining trends are often a defining characteristic of land degradation","source":"

UNCCD 2017. Good Practice Guidance. SDG Indicator 15.3.1. Proportion of land that is degraded over total land area. Version 1.0 Available from: http://www2.unccd.int/sites/default/files/relevant-links/2017-10/Good%20Practice%20Guidance_ SDG%20Indicator%2015.3.1_Version%201.0.pdf

Trends.Earth. Conservation International. Available online at: http://trends.earth. 2018.

", "link":"http://trends.earth"}

attributes.name: Productivity state
attributes.info:
{"description":"State is a comparison of how current productivity in an area compares to past productivity in that area. Land productivity for degradation (2013-2015) compared to (2001-2012) trends in MODIS productivity. Land productivity is the total above-ground net primary productivity defined as the energy fixed by plants minus their respiration which translates into the rate of biomass accumulation that delivers a suite of ecosystem services. This sub-indicator points to changes in the health and productive capacity of the land and reflects the net effects of changes in ecosystem functioning on plant and biomass growth, where declining trends are often a defining characteristic of land degradation","source":"

Trends.Earth. Conservation International. Available online at: http://trends.earth. 2018.

attributes.name: Productivity performance
attributes.info:
{"description":"Performance is a comparison of how productivity in an area compares to productivity in similar areas at the same point in time (2001-2015). Land productivity is the total above-ground net primary productivity defined as the energy fixed by plants minus their respiration which translates into the rate of biomass accumulation that delivers a suite of ecosystem services. This sub-indicator points to changes in the health and productive capacity of the land and reflects the net effects of changes in ecosystem functioning on plant and biomass growth, where declining trends are often a defining characteristic of land degradation", "source":"
